entry.title: Protecting the UK against terrorism
entry.content:
Issue

There is a threat to the UK, British nationals and our interests abroad from terrorism.

The vast majority of these threats come from outside the UK and cannot be resolved by concentrating efforts in the UK alone. The government is addressing these threats at their source overseas before they reach the UK.

Actions

The government’s Counter Terrorism Strategy, CONTEST, reduces the risk from international terrorism so that people can go about their daily lives freely and with confidence.

It is based on 4 main actions:

  • prevent: to stop people from becoming terrorists or supporting terrorism
  • pursue: to stop terrorist attacks
  • protect: to strengthen our protection against terrorist attack
  • prepare: where an attack cannot be stopped, to mitigate its impact

Prevent

We aim to stop people becoming terrorists or supporting terrorism in the UK and abroad.

We do this by:

  • responding to the ideological challenge of terrorism and the threat we face from those who promote it
  • preventing people from being drawn into terrorism and ensuring that they are given appropriate advice and support
  • working with sectors and institutions where there are risks of radicalisation which we need to address

You can find the latest information on the Prevent strategy on the Home Office website. This includes the full text of the strategy and the outcomes of the Prevent review.

Pursue

The Pursue strand of the strategy means working to detect and investigate terrorist networks and disrupt their activities.

We do this by:

  • improving our ability to identify and understand the terrorist threat
  • disrupting terrorist activity and taking action to frustrate terrorist attacks
  • bringing terrorists to justice through prosecution – this includes strengthening the legal framework against terrorism
  • developing international co-operation with partners and allies to strengthen our ability to work together to disrupt terrorist networks, for instance by using Deportation with Assurances

Protect

The Protect strand means seeking to reduce the vulnerability of the UK and its interests overseas from terrorist attack.

We do this by:

  • providing accurate FCO travel advice on the threat from domestic and international terrorism, with advice for British companies abroad
  • supporting key foreign governments to develop their ability to protect areas such as aviation and maritime security, energy infrastructure, crowded places and ‘soft’ targets

Prepare

The Prepare strand means working to mitigate the impact of a terrorist attack where it cannot be stopped. This includes work to manage an ongoing attack and recover from its aftermath.

We do this by:

  • preparing the FCO network to respond to terrorist attacks
  • supporting foreign governments to develop their own ability to respond to terrorism

Advances in technology by both terrorists and organised crime groups create challenges to our national security. The UK’s Science and Technology Strategy for Countering International Terrorism uses innovation, science and technology to reduce the risk to the UK and its interests overseas from international terrorism.

Background

Al Qaeda is weaker than at any time since 9/11. It has played no role in recent political change in North Africa and the Middle East. Its ideology has been widely discredited and it has failed in all its objectives.

Continued international pressure has further reduced its capability and the UK is working with other countries to weaken terrorist threats.

However, al Qaeda continues to be a significant threat and other terrorist groups, some affiliated to al Qaeda, have become stronger.

The Home Office is responsible for keeping the UK safe from the threat posed by terrorism.

The determination of the government and everyone involved in the 2012 Olympic and Paralympic Games was to create a safe and secure event that the UK and the world could enjoy. We thoroughly tested our plans to see how government departments, police and emergency services could respond to a range of incidents.

The games’ safety and security strategy has helped communities become more resilient to crime and the threat from violent extremism, and relationships between police and other security agencies have improved.

In the event of a terrorist incident, the Office for Security and Counter-Terrorism is responsible for activating and co-ordinating the Home Office response. We provide a crisis response 24 hours a day, 365 days of the year. The government’s response to all kinds of emergencies, including terrorism, is set out in the Central government arrangements for responding to an emergency: concept of operations.

entry.title: Conflict minerals
entry.content:
Introduction

Revenue generated by the illegal exploitation of natural resources in the eastern Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) remains a major financial source for armed groups and is a significant contributing factor to conflict. The government, alongside international partners, are working to ensure that the DRC’s mineral wealth is brought under legitimate control, as a source of revenue for the state and the local population, and to restrict financial support to armed groups.

DRC’s mineral wealth is enormous. It is estimated that the country contains 80% of the world’s columbite-tantalite (coltan) reserves, 49% of its cobalt reserves, and 10% of its copper reserves. Gold and diamond deposits remain underexplored, but are estimated to be vast. Conflict minerals are mined in conditions of armed conflict where human rights abuses take place.

DFID and the FCO are working closely with the Government of the DRC and international partners (including the World Bank, European Union and United Nations) to improve governance and management of the DRC minerals sector.

What are conflict minerals?

‘Conflict minerals’ as defined in recent US legislation and international guidance currently being piloted in DRC currently applies to cassiterite, coltan, wolframite and gold, or derivatives of these minerals. Sometimes these minerals are referred to as the ‘three Ts’ - tin, tantalum and tungsten (and gold).

  • Cassiterite - raw tin ore used for solder and can coating, in many alloys and to prevent corrosion
  • Columbite-tantalite or coltan, from which tantalum is extracted and being used primarily in the fabrication of electronic capacitators used in consumer electronic products such as mobile phones, DVD players, and computers
  • Wolframite - the source of tungsten, a strong and dense metal with many military and industry uses
  • Gold

Who mines the conflict minerals?

In DRC various non-state armed groups, such as the Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda (FDLR), but also rogue brigades within the Armed Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (FARDC) – the Congolese national army – are reportedly involved in the production and trade of conflict minerals. While several industrial gold mining companies are exploring for gold in northern and eastern DRC, and several mining companies are producing gold in the DRC’s adjoining countries, artisanal (small-scale, independent) mining is currently the only active mode of production in the conflict-affected parts of eastern DRC.

An artisanal miner is a subsistence miner, not officially employed by a mining company, but working independently, mining or panning for gold using their own resources. 80-90% of mineral production in the DRC is being undertaken by between 1 and 2 million artisanal miners in the DRC who, in turn, support a larger community of 4 -12 million people.

The supply chain

Companies can, knowingly or unknowingly, be affected by the risk of supply chain contamination with conflict minerals. This can occur at a number of stages, whether mining or trading in the eastern provinces of DRC, in an adjoining country, or further along the chain.

Companies, whether at the ‘upstream’ stage of the supply chain (i.e. from mine to smelter) or at the ‘downstream’ stage (i.e. from smelter to end user), are affected by the conflict minerals risk.

Minerals are traded and processed by upstream stakeholders, before being used in downstream manufacturing products. These conflict minerals (cassiterite, coltan, wolframite and gold) are used in the electronics, automotive, aerospace, defence, software, pharmaceutical and other industries.

The DRC remains a difficult business environment and in the conflict-affected parts in the east of the country, some mines are exclusively accessed by artisanal miners, state services, state security forces and/or armed groups. Production from these sites passes through various intermediaries prior to export and is open to exploitation by armed groups.

Recent legislative and regulatory initiatives seek to keep contaminated minerals out of the industry supply chain by requiring companies to prove that minerals are either not from conflict-affected areas (proof of origin) or that their production and trade have not contributed to conflict financing and human rights abuses (due diligence and certification).

These initiatives follow moves in other industries towards improved due diligence and ‘know-your-customer’ requirements which companies based in Western countries, or selling to Western consumers, increasingly have to comply with.

Legislation

Internationally, the key legislative change is the United-States Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (the Dodd-Frank Act), section 1502 on Conflict Minerals (formerly known as the Congo Conflict Minerals Act). It applies to all companies that report to the US Security and Exchange Commission (SEC).

The UK Bribery Act holds UK firms accountable for bribery, whether committed directly and on their behalf, in the UK or overseas.

Further information

  • map of militarised mining areas in the Kivus (August 2009)
  • UN Security Council Committee reports on DRC
  • OECD risk awareness tool for multinational enterprises in weak governance zones
  • OECD Due Diligence Guidelines

entry.title: Work experience at the Foreign and Commonwealth Office
entry.content:
The Foreign and Commonwealth Office (FCO) aims to recruit a talented and diverse workforce which reflects the society we serve. Our recruitment policies are therefore designed to encourage applications from the widest range of backgrounds.

By offering work experience opportunities, we hope to encourage young people to consider the FCO as a future employer, as well as offering them beneficial work experience. Given our aim above, we are focusing our work experience opportunities on individuals from backgrounds that are currently under-represented in our workforce; and on those who bring skills which we require to achieve our objectives. These currently include, in particular, hard languages and economics.

The FCO Future Talent Scheme

This is a scheme run by the FCO for students in their penultimate year of university. The scheme is split into 2 strands.

  1. Firstly we are targeting female undergraduates of any background studying any degree at any UK university. This strand is aimed at increasing our future pool of female applicants to the fast stream, as they are currently under-represented.

  2. The second strand targets undergraduates of any background at any UK university who are studying Arabic, Mandarin, Japanese, Farsi, Dari, Pashtu, Russian or economics. This strand is aimed at attracting future applicants to our fast stream who have important skills for the FCO.

We will be taking 10 students from each strand for a 4-week placement during the summer (August to September). Students will be paid during their placement. They will get training in areas such as interview skills, and will be assigned to teams within departments across the FCO with a line manager responsible for their induction and development.

The FCO Future Talent Scheme for 2012 is now over. Information about future FCO work experience internship schemes will appear here.

Economic Sandwich Students Placement Scheme

Every year, the FCO offers a 1-year placement opportunity to 4 economics undergraduates. The successful candidates will work in our Economics Unit, the Commercial and Economic Diplomacy Department, or the EU Directorate. This is an excellent opportunity for students to gain valuable work experience, using their economic skills to support the FCO’s work across a range of foreign policy issues. Students will be based at the FCO’s Headquarters in Whitehall.

What will I be doing?

Students will be involved in a range of activities across economic, policy and corporate work. These are likely to include:

  • providing briefings for ministers or ambassadors
  • working on political lobbying and supporting political processes
  • compiling economic reports, for example, on international development, trade and EU issues
  • providing research support for economists, including statistical analysis
  • maintaining and editing the FCO’s economics website
  • contributing to foreign policy papers requiring economic input or analysis
  • taking responsibility for an area of corporate activity, for example, as a first aider or fire marshal

Have I got what you’re looking for?

We are looking for economics students with an interest in current and foreign affairs. Students will need to have a very good knowledge of economics and a good awareness of economic issues in a foreign policy context. The successful candidates will have good communication skills (written and oral), be able to deliver results and have strong inter-personal skills.

When do placements take place?

Placements start in the summer (June/July) and last for 12 months. Precise start dates will be negotiated with successful candidates.

Will I get paid?

Yes. Successful candidates will be paid £19,245 plus a London Location Allowance of £3,520. Placement students will also qualify (after 3 months’ employment) for an advance of salary to meet the cost of travel fares. The FCO offers a loan to students who are interested in purchasing a bike for home-to-office travel.

What are the eligibility criteria?

To be eligible you must:

  • be an undergraduate between your penultimate and final year of study at the time of the placement
  • have 3 A-level passes at grades A to C (or equivalent)
  • be on a degree course where at least half of the course is economics-based
  • be available to start work in June/July 2013 for 12 months
  • be a British citizen and have been resident in the UK for at least 2 of the previous 10 years, at least 1 year of which must have been a consecutive 12-month period

Security clearance

Successful candidates must undergo security clearance before being formally appointed. All applicants should be aware that a lack of sufficient background information could prevent an applicant from being granted clearance.

How do I apply?

Applications can be made through the GES Sandwich Student Placement.

entry.title: International secondments for the Foreign and Commonwealth Office
entry.content:
The UK supports international efforts to prevent violent conflict, to resolve existing conflicts, and to build peace in post-conflict situations.

In support of this, the FCO seconds civilian experts and police (serving and retired officers) to international missions run by the European Union (EU), United Nations (UN) and Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE).

These missions include:

  • European Police Mission in Afghanistan (EUPOL Afghanistan)
  • EU Monitoring Mission in Georgia (EUMM Georgia)
  • EU Integrated Rule of Law Mission for Iraq, (EU JUSTLEX)
  • European Rule of Law Mission in Kosovo (EULEX Kosovo)
  • European Union Police Mission in Bosnia and Herzegovina (EUPM)
  • several OSCE missions in the Balkans and Caucasus

Policing roles in international missions fall into 5 main categories:

  • executive policing - the UN Mission in Kosovo (UNMIK) is the only mission where executive policing is carried out
  • training - general police duties, counter-insurgency, counter-terrorism, firearms and human rights
  • monitoring and reporting - for example, security and protection, control room operators and finance
  • mentoring and advising - for example, organised crime, criminal intelligence, community policing
  • programme and project management - for example, strategic intelligence, strategic police training

Civilian roles fall into the following categories:

  • border monitoring
  • running field offices and missions
  • human rights
  • rule of law
  • media
  • programme management
  • police training
  • political affairs
  • good governance
  • promoting democracy

Opportunities for police officers

British police officers are deployed to Peace Support Operations to reform domestic police forces and help them build the respect and confidence of the local community. Less frequently, they may carry out executive policing duties. International policing missions also have an important role in the fight against organised, cross-border crime.

Recruitment and selection

The International Secondments Team (IST) writes to Chief Constables and Police Forces HR departments once a year with an application pack detailing the missions the FCO is expecting to make contributions to over the following year. Interested officers are asked to apply through their Home Force, and not directly to IST.

When vacancies become available, officers are offered a place through their Force and then complete training before being deployed to a Mission.

Pre-deployment training and administration

Medical examinations are conducted immediately prior to pre-deployment training. Pre-deployment training covers a wide range of areas including life in mission, mine awareness, firearms, first aid, training with language assistants, political and legal briefings, and scenario based training for the roles officers will carry out in specific missions. In addition, those selected for a position in Iraq also undertake a 2-week firearms course.

The Ministry of Defence Police (MDP) holds a stock of kit which officers can try on during their pre-deployment course.

Secondment agreement

Once the secondment agreement is signed, a letter of approval for overseas service is issued by the Home Office, the Northern Ireland Office or Scottish Executive under the relevant Police Act. Secondments are for a period of 12 months. Extensions can be requested through the mission locally, apart from those who have been deployed to Iraq or Afghanistan where extensions cannot be requested (unless there is a strong operational case).

Deployment

IST also appoints a Contingent Commander to each Mission. The Contingent Commander undertakes this role in addition to the job they are assigned by the mission. The Contingent Commander is the UK officers’ first point of contact for welfare, personnel and other support issues. They are also responsible for ensuring that appraisals are completed on time, managing leave and channelling extension requests to IST.

Performance and Development Review and Appraisal System (PDR)

The PDR process helps officers set objectives and to record the performance and development of new skills whilst abroad. This is also a very helpful tool to the FCO in assessing officers’ experiences in the field and their contribution to the peacekeeping mission in which they serve. The appraisal form is similar to the Police Performance Development Review and its compatibility with the existing police appraisal system should help integrate international experience with the officer’s domestic career.

Return and reintegration

Under ACPO guidelines, Chief Officers are encouraged to give officers a block of 28 days leave when they return to the UK at the end of their deployment, though this remains at the discretion of the officer’s Force. Officers will be invited to a re-integration course at MDP Wethersfield at which they are able to discuss any issues they had at post, e.g. with equipment, and make suggestions for future missions. This is very useful to officers and allows the FCO to look at areas for improvement for future deployments.

Opportunities for civilians

The UK government supports promoting effective rule of law, governance, stabilisation, confidence-building and normalisation in conflict-affected and fragile states.

Currently, the FCO, through the Stabilisation Unit and on behalf of the government, supports the secondment of UK civilian experts to multinational Common Security and Defence Policy missions and EU Special Representative Offices.

CSDP Missions

Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP) missions provide international expertise, advice and support to countries at risk of instability; that are currently unstable, or recovering from conflict.

Despite the fact that CSDP was conceived largely as a military project, the majority of the 27 missions deployed since 2003 have been civilian. They work on a wide variety of conflict prevention and peace-building tasks.

There are currently 12 civilian CSDP missions, 7 of which have UK civilian experts seconded to them:

  • the EU Police Mission in Afghanistan (EUPol Afghanistan)
  • the EU Monitoring Mission in Georgia (EUMM Georgia)
  • the EU Integrated Rule of Law Mission for Iraq, (EUJUST LEX Iraq)
  • the EU Rule of Law Mission in Kosovo (EULEX Kosovo)
  • the EU Police Co-ordinating Office for Palestinian Police Support (EUPol COPPS)
  • the EU Regional Maritime Capacity Building for the Horn of Africa and the Western Indian Ocean (EUCAP NESTOR)
  • the EU Aviation Security Mission in South Sudan (EUAVSEC South Sudan)

EU Special Representative Offices

  • the Office of the EU Special Representative to Bosnia and Herzegovina (EUSR Bosnia)
  • the Office of the EU Special Representative for the South Caucasus and Crisis in Georgia
  • the Office of the EU Special Representative in Kosovo (EUSR Kosovo)

Recruitment and selection

Each multilateral mission advertises its vacancies to member states. Member states, through their international authority (which for the UK is the FCO), decide which roles they wish to support based on their strategic priorities for that mission. The Stabilisation Unit (SU) is responsible for managing the recruitment and deployment process for those roles.

Adverts are published to the UK Civilian Stabilisation Group, and to other relevant organisations. Only UK nationals are eligible to apply for these roles. Interested applicants are requested to complete an application form (which is attached to the advert) and submit their CV. The FCO and SU review applications and decide which candidate to nominate to the respective multilateral organisation. That multilateral institution will interview and decide which member state’s candidate is suitable for the vacancy. For further information, you can contact SU Recruitment.

Pre-deployment training

Successful candidates are required to undertake pre-deployment training prior to deployment. The Stabilisation Unit will arrange for individuals to undertake a medical assessment, a hostile environment training course, briefings, and any other relevant training.

For secondees deploying to missions that require kit and equipment, the SU holds a stock of kit and equipment which will be provided to secondees prior to deployment.

Tour length

Secondments are on a fixed term 1-year contract with the FCO. An extension may be requested, but must come from the respective mission authority.

Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe

Positions in the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) vary from the standard secondment process. OSCE vacancies are advertised on the OSCE website. The FCO does not pay a salary for most of these roles. Instead, the OSCE pays a board and lodging allowance to successful candidates. The FCO, through their International Organisations Department, invite interested individuals to complete the OSCE application form (also found on the employment page of the OSCE website). Completed application forms should be sent to: SU Recruitment.

Current vacancies

The Stabilisation Unit would like to invite applications from suitably qualified people for the following positions in EUPOL COPPS Palestine. Full details and job descriptions below.

We welcome applications for:

HoMS06 Staff and Liaison Officer ProgS01 Head of Programmes (Various) Police Advisor (Various) Senior Police Advisor ProgS03 Programmes Advisor (Monitoring & Evaluation)

After sifting, Stabilisation Unit will nominate up to three positions. Please indicate on your application form, or covering email which positions you are interested in being nominated for. All positions are for 12 months initially.

For civil servants we are looking for officers at Grade 6 (DFID A1/MoD B1/ FCO D7) or Grade 7 (DFID A2/ MOD B2/ FCO D6). Civil servants are responsible for organising their own secondment or unpaid leave.

Requirements

You must be fit and able to work in a non-benign environment, and be willing to attend a Hostile Environment Awareness Training course. You must be a UK National.

These positions require security clearance to EU Secret (equivalent to UK SC clearance). You must either hold this or be willing to undertake the clearance process, if you are successful with your application.

You must have a valid driving licence. More details on the driving requirement are contained in the Job Description document.

How to apply:

The EU post requirements will be the basis for the initial sifting of applications. The initial sift will be completed by the FCO and Stabilisation Unit. The nominated candidate will be sent to the EU for consideration against other member state applicants. The interview and final selection process is completed by the EU.

Applicants should send their completed EU application form along with a copy of their CV and a covering email to SU Recruitment by 9.00 Tuesday 6th November. Cadre and civil servants should also include their last two appraisal reports and copy to line management and appropriate home department HR contact.

With your application form, you should include the following in your covering email:

  • whether you have ever completed Hostile Environment Training, and if so, when and where
  • what level of security clearance you hold, when it was issued and by whom
  • your availability, including the earliest start date you can offer the Mission
  • which positions you are interested in

As we deal with a large number of applicants, we regret that we are unable to give individual feedback. However, we do consider each application carefully and select applicants who best match the requirements.

entry.title: Reuniting Europe programme: bidding process
entry.content:
Overview

The Reuniting Europe programme supports partner countries with the reforms necessary for EU accession or closer partnership with the EU. The programme helps to build an effective and globally competitive EU and to maintain and improve the EU’s security.

Programme objectives

EU enlargement has been a major success, helping reunite a continent divided by the Cold War and helping us to respond to the opportunities and challenges of globalisation. It is strongly in our interest to maintain the momentum of the enlargement process, including the accession negotiations with Turkey and Croatia, and on bringing peace and stability to the Western Balkans. We also want to ensure that we share our prosperity and stability with our wider neighbourhood.

The programme helps European partner countries to implement the reforms necessary for EU accession and looks at stable institutions guaranteeing democracy, the rule of law, human rights and the respect for and protection of minorities. It aims to:

  • support political reforms and undertake political advocacy
  • increase political transparency and good governance
  • build capacity in public administration
  • strengthen reforms in the justice sector
  • promote human rights

Further details of the rationale behind the selection of these objectives and guidelines on the kinds of projects sought are contained in the Diplomatic Influence and Values (DIV) Fund 2011/12, which includes a full break-down of the revised Programme indicators.

Diplomatic Influence and Values (DIV) Fund 2011/12

To request this document in an alternative format such as braille, audio or a different file type please email webmaster@fco.gov.uk quoting your address, telephone number along with the title of the publication ("Diplomatic Influence and Values (DIV) Fund 2011/12").

All project bids will need to contribute to the achievement of at least 1 of the specific indicators developed for each programme objective.

Target countries

Albania Bosnia and Herzegovina Croatia Kosovo Macedonia Montenegro Serbia Turkey

Programme operating principles

The Reuniting Europe Programme is one of many programmes of the wider Diplomatic Influence and Values Fund. The programme will:

  • be 100% ODA-able (meeting the OECD criteria on Official Development Assistance)
  • focus on building capacity and efficiency in organisational structures and processes for policy-making, and in establishing the regulatory framework for effective policy implementation
  • focus on fields where the UK has specific expertise to offer or is better equipped than other potential partners to meet the local need
  • pursue harmonisation with other donors through, where appropriate, co-funding arrangements or projects to pump-prime, pilot or underpin the sustainability of larger-scale projects led by other donors which support the UK’s objectives
  • encourage the development of projects using New Member State expertise
  • operate in areas that avoid duplication and maximise complementarity with the work of other UK government funding sources
  • support UK objectives in each country/region and facilitate FCO action, enhancing the UK’s diplomatic effort

Bidding process

Projects should be at a minimum of £20,000 and those spanning up to 3 financial years will be considered. Please note we do not fund academic courses or research, or English language courses.

The Project Officers in the FCO office in the target country are responsible for developing project ideas and managing the projects. When the London Programme Team issue a call for bids, Project Officers at overseas posts will ask implementers to draw up a concept bid.

entry.title: Chevening Scholarships for students from overseas
entry.content:
Overview

Chevening Scholarships are the UK government’s global scholarships programme. Established in 1983, these scholarships support study at UK universities – mostly one-year Masters’ degrees – for students with the demonstrable potential to become future leaders, decision-makers and opinion formers across a wide range of fields, including politics, business, the media, civil society, religion, and academia.

If you have the potential to be a future leader and a desire to study in the UK, sign up and find out more

Eligibility

Chevening Scholarships are currently offered in approximately 110 countries, in most regions of the world. In the current academic year, there are over 700 Chevening scholars at universities across the UK. Those selected will be high-calibre graduates with the personal, intellectual and interpersonal qualities necessary for leadership. They will be citizens of any country other than the UK or another European Union country or the United States of America.

Chevening Scholarships are mainly funded by the Foreign and Commonwealth Office (FCO), with some contributions from universities and other partners in the UK and overseas, including governmental and private sector bodies.

History

The Chevening Scholarships programme started in 1984, as the Foreign and Commonwealth Office Scholarships and Awards Scheme.

In 1994, the name of the scheme was changed to Chevening, after Chevening House in Sevenoaks, Kent – currently the joint official residence of the Foreign Secretary and the Deputy Prime Minister.

Since the scheme began, over 40,000 students have held Chevening Scholarships. Many have gone on to reach positions of influence in a range of sectors. Famous alumni include:

  • Sergei Stanishev - former Prime Minister of Bulgaria; currently President of the Party of European Socialists
  • Alvaro Uribe Velez - former President of Colombia
  • Baldwin Spencer - Prime Minister of Antigua and Barbuda
  • Jorma Ollila - Non-Executive Chairman of Royal Dutch Shell; Non-Executive Chairman of Nokia
  • Maged Shawki - former Chairman of the Cairo and Alexandria Stock Exchange
  • Xu Shandu - Vice-Minister for Tax Administration, People’s Republic of China
  • Vahram Kazhoyan - UNESCO Chair, Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Armenia
  • Tigran Mkrtchyan - Adviser to the Minister of Foreign Affairs, Armenia
  • Nittish Mishra - Cabinet Minister, Bihar State, India
  • Jaime Bermudez - Minister of Foreign Affairs, Colombia
  • Anote Tong - President of Kiribati
  • Marek Belka - former Prime Minister of Poland; currently Head of the National Bank of Poland
  • Joao Miranda - former Minister for Foreign Affairs, Angola
  • Giga Bokeria - Secretary of the National Security Council, Georgia
  • Gega Mgaloblishvili - former Prime Minister of Georgia; currently Georgian Ambassador to NATO
  • Chong Hiu Yeung - General Secretary of the Hong Kong Journalists Association
  • Normans Penke - former State Secretary of the Latvian Ministry of Foreign Affairs; currently Latvian Ambassador to the UN
  • Irena Radovic - former Deputy Foreign Affairs Minister, Montenegro; currently Montenegrin Ambassador to Republic of France with ambassador accreditations for the UNESCO and Principality of Monaco
  • Wang Lili - Vice Governor of the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China
  • Bozidarka Dodik - War Crimes Prosecutor, State Prosecutor’s Office of Bosnia and Herzegovina

How to apply

Applications for 2013/14 Chevening Scholarships are now open.

If you have the potential to be a future leader and a desire to study in the UK, you can find out more and apply now

For full information about eligibility and selection criteria please read the guidance for applicants, which contains precise rules and regulations about the application process for 2013 to 2014 Chevening Scholarships.

entry.title: Domestic Programme Fund: bidding process
entry.content:
Overview

The Domestic Programme Fund (DPF) provides funding to charities for small projects in the UK. The Forced Marriage Unit (FMU) recognises that protecting victims and ending forced marriage can only be achieved if all partners across government, non-governmental organisations and statutory agencies work collectively.

The DPF promotes this joined-up approach of working by encouraging and enabling voluntary organisations to contribute even more to the wide and varied ongoing work to protect victims and end the abusive act of forced marriage. This has been demonstrated even more than ever this year with £150,000 now being made available. You can view the list of successful projects from 2012 to 2013, below.

Bidding process

The DPF bidding round for 2012 to 2013 is now closed. Please check this page next year for the next DPF bidding round for 2013 to 2014 with details of how to apply.

Successful projects 2012 to 13

Ann Craft Trust – Forced Marriage and Learning Disabilities Guidance

This project is an in-depth survey of local Safeguarding Children’s Boards in addition to Safeguarding Adult Boards in England and Wales to identify how many have specific protocols on dealing with forced marriage of people with learning disabilities embedded in safeguarding policies and/or training. Outcomes will support the facilitation of an enhanced role and understanding in education, health care, social care and other agencies working with children and vulnerable adults. This programme of work will also enable the mapping of services that are provided both locally and regionally.

AVA in association with Animage Films: ‘The Dancer’ animated forced marriage film

A short animated film will be developed to address this contentious issue – it will promote further discussion and raise awareness in the public domain. The film will not only act as an information portal but also to let victims and those at risk of forced marriage to know how to find help and seek further advice. All supporting material produced can also be used extensively in schools and colleges on request, and the film will be made available to all organisations and media agencies who would like to distribute and screen it.

Eaves Housing for Women: empowering young people to prevent forced marriage

The project aims to tackle forced marriage by challenging the practice head on, through working with victims and communities to overcome the culture of acceptance or of denial. It will provide an environment for young - 16 to 25 year old - BAME people to express their views on forced marriage, support each other and ultimately become drivers for change. The project addresses two main themes of prevention and provision in that it seeks to prevent forced marriage and develop better responses when the potential risk arises. It will not only provide young people with a voice but also gives them the confidence to use that voice in preventing forced marriages.

JAN Trust: Mujboor Project (Urdu – Forced against my will)

This project will look to adopt a grass roots led approach to combating forced marriages, utilising dialogue with communities, education and training of those relevant service providers as part of the way to improving the enforcement of legislation. By working collaboratively with faith groups and religious leaders in North and West London, the project will raise awareness of forced marriage and challenge a number of the perceived misconceptions and behaviours that currently tolerate forced marriage. This model has already demonstrated it is an effective approach in other regions and will continue to target perpetrators, victims and potential victims.

Centre for Family Law and Practice: college and university responses to forced marriage

Following the recently published pilot study examining university responses to forced marriage and violence against women in March 2012, this project aims to widen the evidence base and now include colleges and other universities. The long-term aim will be to develop the capacity of these institutions to offer appropriate support and referrals to students who may have been threatened by, or have experienced, forced marriage either themselves, or know of others in that position. The project also seeks to identify any emerging and promising practice in terms of on-campus support, partnership working between the third sector and statutory agencies, gaps in responses and areas for improvement. By expanding knowledge of proper campus responses to forced marriage, the proposed research will contribute to better for students and a firmer societal response to forced marriage.

New Vic Theatre: ‘All Our Daughters?’

The proposal has been put together in response to numerous requests from NGOs and local authorities for the ‘All Our Daughter’s?’ play and workshops. The project aims to build on the success of the initial play and tour of the ‘All Our Daughters?’ by delivering regional training conferences for professionals, voluntary sector and community members. Both the play and accompanying workshops will form part of a tour in schools and colleges, and communities across four regions following each conference. The DVD and work-pack for agencies will be made available to be posted online via a range of partner websites - extending the life of the project. All of this of work will contribute towards forming a national network of partners to keep forced marriage and honour based violence on local agenda’s, and create further opportunities for communication and debate.

Southall Black Sisters (SBS) – Enhanced provision of advice and support for victims of forced marriage

The project will help with the provision of information, advice and advocacy, once victims have been placed in safe temporary accommodation. The work will also involve assistance with applications for permanent housing, reporting and prosecution of crimes, obtaining FMPOs, obtaining divorce or annulment papers, accessing counselling, benefits, friendship networks, educational and work opportunities. SBS will also provide advice, assistance and training for other organisations across the country on how to help and support repatriated victims in their local area.

St Phillips Centre, Leicester: ‘Love, Honour and Obey’, a forced marriage role play

The project will explore forced marriages with women from Leicester, through a fictitious role play about a girl and her lead up to the forced marriage. Participants will play roles and their decisions will then go on to determine outcomes. The project will encourage discussion and debate in a safe environment on a number of related issues and consider barriers created by cultural and religious sensitivities. The learning will lead to the development of storyboards to raise awareness – to be launched at an event in April 2013, for free use by schools, community centres and faith & voluntary organisations to use as a tool to raise awareness. The St Philip’s Centre has access to the key communities where this is an issue and can access the key locations and individuals where changes need to be made.

West of Scotland Regional Equality Council: ‘Not in our Name’

This project will develop the ability of young men from South Asian backgrounds who are living in Glasgow and beyond, to understand and address forced marriage in their communities. We will support the dissemination of relevant information in a male context both as being at risk or supporting a family member who is at risk. We will involve and enable young men to spread this information across their communities and beyond by building their knowledge and confidence through training and the production of support materials.

entry.title: Marshall Scholarships for American students
entry.content:
Overview

Up to 40 Americans are selected each year to study at graduate level at UK institutions in any field of study.

As future leaders, with a lasting understanding of British society, Marshall Scholars strengthen the enduring relationship between the British and American peoples, their governments and their institutions. Marshall Scholars are talented, independent and wide-ranging, and their time as scholars enhances their intellectual and personal growth. Their direct engagement with Britain through its best academic programmes contributes to their ultimate personal success.

The Marshall Scholarships website has all the information and application details. Find out more.

Eligibility

The funding is for United States citizens who (at the time they take up their scholarship) hold a first degree from an accredited four-year college or university in the United States with a minimum GPA of 3.7. The degree must have been awarded within the past 3 years.

The award includes university fees, cost of living expenses, annual book grant, thesis grant, research and daily travel grants, fares to and from the United States and, where applicable, a contribution towards the support of a dependent spouse.

History

Marshall Scholarships are mainly funded by the Foreign & Commonwealth Office (FCO) and are overseen by the Marshall Aid Commemoration Commission. They were founded by a 1953 Act of Parliament, and named in honour of US Secretary of State George C Marshall. The scholarships commemorate the humane ideals of the Marshall Plan and they express the continuing gratitude of the British people to their American counterparts.

How to apply

The application round starts in the spring of the previous year.

The Marshall Scholarships website has all the information and application details. Find out more.

entry.title: Leading international efforts to resolve concerns about Iran's nuclear programme
entry.content:
Issue

Despite Iran’s claim that its nuclear programme is peaceful, Britain shares international concerns that the programme may also have a military purpose.

Iran is making a disproportionate investment in the parts of the nuclear fuel cycle that could be used for a weapons programme. We are particularly concerned about the enrichment of uranium to 20% without a credible civilian use for it. The concealment of elements of Iran’s nuclear programme - eg hiding a nuclear facility at Qom until 2009 - is another concern.

Iran is also in defiance of 6 UN Security Council resolutions. It hasn’t cooperated fully with the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) by providing them access for inspections. It also signed but then failed to implement an Additional Protocol, which would have given the IAEA authority to properly assess its nuclear activities. The IAEA says that this lack of cooperation means it can’t confirm that all Iran’s nuclear material is for peaceful activities.

The UK, along with much of the international community, is deeply concerned about the consequences for regional security if Iran develops nuclear weapons.

Actions

The international community is seeking a peaceful, negotiated solution and is applying pressure on Iran through:

  • diplomatic engagement - the UK, US, France, Germany, China and Russia have held regular talks with Iran since 2012 and these are ongoing
  • economic incentives - if Iran demonstrates that it isn’t developing a nuclear weapon then the permanent members of the UN Security Council will help it develop more nuclear power stations and give it economic, agricultural and humanitarian assistance
  • economic pressure - the UK, the EU and the UN have enforced sanctions targeting Iran’s nuclear programme and its banking, oil and gas sectors

Background

Diplomatic relations between the UK and Iran have been cut off and restored several times since the 1979 Revolution. On 29 November 2011, student Basij militia entered the British embassy in Tehran and a residential compound in the north of the city, causing extensive damage. The Iranian authorities made no credible effort to intervene. The embassy is now closed and all British diplomats have been withdrawn. All Iranian diplomats were ordered to leave the UK on 2 December 2011.

Diplomatic relations haven’t been completely severed, but they are at a minimal level. Sweden now represents British interests in Iran through their embassy in Tehran, while Iran’s interests in the UK are currently represented by the Sultanate of Oman through its embassy in London.

Iran has backed Hizbollah in Lebanon, as well as Hamas and other Palestinian Rejectionist groups. It supports anti-government militia groups in Iraq and the Taliban in Afghanistan. All this undermines international efforts to bring about stability and security in these countries, and has caused serious tension between Iran and its neighbours.
